anchor.surface_text: We agree that seduction to illicit intercourse companytemplated by the section does number mean merely straying from the path of virtue by a female for the first time. The verb seduce is used in two senses. It is used in its ordinary and narrow, sense as inducing, a woman to stray from the path of virtue for the first time it is also used in the wider sense of educing a woman to submit to illicit intercourse at any time or on any occasion. It is in the latter sense that the expression has been used in as. 366 and 366A of the Indian Penal Code which sections partially overlap. This view has been taken in a large number of cases by the Superior Courts in India, e. g. Prafula kumar Basu v. The Emperor  1 , Emperor v. Laxman Bala  1 , Krishna Maharana v. The King Emperor  3 , In re Khalandar Saheb  4  Suppiah v. Emperor  5 , Pessumal v. Emperor  6 , King Emperor v. Nga Ni Ta  7  and Kartara v. The State  8 .

concepts.interpretation: In ss.366/366A, 'seduce' used in wider sense (illicit intercourse any time), not narrow (first time only). Requires overcoming reluctance via persuasion etc.; habitual prostitute offering services for money not 'seduced' as no reluctance.

issues.text: Whether the appellant can in law be held guilty of abetting the commission of an offence punishable under s. 366A, Indian Penal Code, by Patilba.

anchor.surface_text: Bohori Kathada. In our view, the appellant cannot in law be held guilty of abetting the commission of an offence punishable under s. 366A, Indian Penal Code, by Patilba. The facts proved by the evidence are these Anusaya at the material time had not attained the age of 18 years.

issues.text: Whether there is evidence that Patilba induced Anusaya to go to the theatre or from the theatre to Bohori Kathada, or whether merely accompanying a minor prostitute plying her trade constitutes inducement under s. 366A.

anchor.surface_text: But there is numberevidence on the record that Patilba induced Anusaya to go to the theratre or from the theatre to the Bohori Kathada. It must be assumed that when Patilba accompanied Anusaya to the theatre and from the theatre to the Bohori Kathada at the suggestion of the appellant he knew that she was going for plying her profession as a prostitute.

issues.text: What are the principal ingredients of the offence under s. 366A.

anchor.surface_text: Section 366A was enacted by Act XX of 1923 to give effect to certain Articles of the International Convention for the Suppression of Traffic in Women and Children signed by various nations at Paris on May 4, 1910. There are three principal ingredients of the offence a that a minor girl below the age of 18 years is induceed by the accused, b that she is induced to go from any place or to do any act, and c that she is so induced with intent that she may be or knowing that it is likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person,

issues.text: Whether 'seduction to illicit intercourse' under ss. 366 and 366A applies to a habitual prostitute offering services promiscuously for money, or requires overcoming reluctance.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that seduction to illicit intercourse contemplated by the section does number mean merely straying from the path of virtue by a female for the first time. The verb seduce is used in two senses. It is used in its ordinary and narrow, sense as inducing, a woman to stray from the path of virtue for the first time it is also used in the wider sense of educing a woman to submit to illicit intercourse at any time or on any occasion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly companyvicted the appellant of the offence under s. 366A read with s. 109 of the Indian Penal Code, because, in their view, he had abetted the companymission of an offence punishable under s. 366A by Patilba by instigating the latter to bring Anusaya to the theatre and by by further instigating Patilba and Devidas to bring Anusaya from the theatre to Bohori Kathada. In our view, the appellant cannot in law be held guilty of abetting the companymission of an offence punishable under s. 366A, Indian Penal Code, by Patilba.

arguments.claim: Merely accompanying a minor prostitute plying her trade does not constitute inducement under s.366A.

anchor.surface_text: It must be assumed that when Patilba accompanied Anusaya to the theatre and from the theatre to the Bohori Kathada at the suggestion of the appellant he knew that she was going for plying her profession as a prostitute. But in our judgment a person who merely accompanies a woman going out to ply her profession of a prostitute, even if she has number attained the age of eighteen years, does number thereby companymit an offence under s. 366A of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Principal ingredients of s.366A: (a) minor girl induced by accused, (b) to go from place or do act, (c) with intent/knowledge she will be forced/seduced to illicit intercourse.

anchor.surface_text: Section 366A was enacted by Act XX of 1923 to give effect to certain Articles of the International Convention for the Suppression of Traffic in Women and Children signed by various nations at Paris on May 4, 1910. There are three principal ingredients of the offence a that a minor girl below the age of 18 years is induceed by the accused, b that she is induced to go from any place or to do any act, and c that she is so induced with intent that she may be or knowing that it is likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person,

arguments.claim: 'Seduce' in ss.366/366A means in wider sense of inducing submission to illicit intercourse any time, not just first time; supported by precedents.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that seduction to illicit intercourse companytemplated by the section does number mean merely straying from the path of virtue by a female for the first time. The verb seduce is used in two senses. [...] This view has been taken in a large number of cases by the Superior Courts in India, e. g. Prafula kumar Basu v. The Emperor...

arguments.claim: View that 'seduce' limited to first act is unduly restrictive given legislative object.

anchor.surface_text: The view expressed to the companytrary in Emperor v. Baijnath  9 , Saheb Ali v. Emperor  11  Aswini Kumar Roy v. The State  10  and Nara v. Emperor  12  that the phrase used in s. 366 of the Indian Penal Code is Properly applicable to the first act of illicit intercourse [...] is having regard to the object of the Legislature unduly restrictive of the companytent of the expression seduce used in the Code.

arguments.claim: Assisting habitual prostitute offering services promiscuously for money does not constitute forcing/seducing under s.366A as no reluctance to overcome.

anchor.surface_text: But where a woman follows the profession of a prostitute, that is, she is accustomed to offer herself promiscuously for money to customers, and in following that profession she is encouraged or assisted by someone, numberoffence under s. 366A is companymitted by such person, for it cannot be said that the person who assists a girl accustomed to indulge in promiscuous intercourse for money in carrying on her profession acts with intent or knowledge that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse.

arguments.claim: Seduction implies overcoming reluctance via persuasion etc.; no seduction where prostitute offers services professionally.

anchor.surface_text: Seduction implies surrender of her body by a woman who is otherwise reluctant or unwilling to submit herself to illicit intercourse in companysequence of persuasion, flattery, blandishment or importunity, whether such surrender is for the first time or is preceded by similar surrender on earlier occasions. But where a woman offers herself for intercourse for money-not casually but in the companyrse of her profession as a prostitute there are numberscruples number reluctance to be overcome, and surrender by her is number seduction within the Code.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that seduction to illicit intercourse companytemplated by the section does number mean merely straying from the path of virtue by a female for the first time. The verb seduce is used in two senses. It is used in its ordinary and narrow, sense as inducing, a woman to stray from the path of virtue for the first time it is also used in the wider sense of educing a woman to submit to illicit intercourse at any time or on any occasion. It is in the latter sense that the expression has been used in as. 366 and 366A of the Indian Penal Code which sections partially overlap.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows superior court precedents interpreting 'seduce' in wider sense; distinguishes narrower views as restrictive

holdings.text: where a woman follows the profession of a prostitute... and in following that profession she is encouraged or assisted by someone, no offence under s. 366A is committed by such person, for it cannot be said that the person who assists a girl accustomed to indulge in promiscuous intercourse for money in carrying on her profession acts with intent or knowledge that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse

holdings.reasoning_summary: Habitual professional prostitution lacks force/seduction element as no reluctance; purposive interpretation aligned with legislative object

holdings.text: Seduction implies surrender of her body by a woman who is otherwise reluctant or unwilling to submit herself to illicit intercourse in consequence of persuasion, flattery, blandishment or importunity... But where a woman offers herself for intercourse for money... in the course of her profession as a prostitute there are no scruples no reluctance to be overcome, and surrender by her is not seduction within the Code

But where a woman offers herself for intercourse for money-not casually but in the companyrse of her profession as a prostitute there are numberscruples number reluctance to be overcome, and surrender by her is number seduction within the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines 'seduction' requiring overcoming reluctance; professional surrender lacks this

anchor.surface_text: Section 366A was enacted by Act XX of 1923 to give effect to certain Articles of the International Convention for the Suppression of Traffic in Women and Children signed by various nations at Paris on May 4, 1910. There are three principal ingredients of the offence a that a minor girl below the age of 18 years is induceed by the accused, b that she is induced to go from any place or to do any act, and c that she is so induced with intent that she may be or knowing that it is likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person,
On May 1, 1962, we ordered after arguments were companycluded that the appeal be allowed and the companyviction of the appellant be set aside.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 interprets 'seduction to illicit intercourse contemplated by the section', addressing the issue of application to habitual prostitute.

anchor.surface_text: We agree that seduction to illicit intercourse companytemplated by the section does number mean merely straying from the path of virtue by a female for the first time. The verb seduce is used in two senses. It is used in its ordinary and narrow, sense as inducing, a woman to stray from the path of virtue for the first time it is also used in the wider sense of educing a woman to submit to illicit intercourse at any time or on any occasion. It is in the latter sense that the expression has been used in as. 366 and 366A of the Indian Penal Code which sections partially overlap.
On May 1, 1962, we ordered after arguments were companycluded that the appeal be allowed and the companyviction of the appellant be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: But where a woman follows the profession of a prostitute, that is, she is accustomed to offer herself promiscuously for money to customers, and in following that profession she is encouraged or assisted by someone, numberoffence under s. 366A is companymitted by such person, for it cannot be said that the person who assists a girl accustomed to indulge in promiscuous intercourse for money in carrying on her profession acts with intent or knowledge that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse.
On May 1, 1962, we ordered after arguments were companycluded that the appeal be allowed and the companyviction of the appellant be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Seduction implies surrender of her body by a woman who is otherwise reluctant or unwilling to submit herself to illicit intercourse in companysequence of persuasion, flattery, blandishment or importunity, whether such surrender is for the first time or is preceded by similar surrender on earlier occasions. But where a woman offers herself for intercourse for money-not casually but in the companyrse of her profession as a prostitute there are numberscruples number reluctance to be overcome, and surrender by her is number seduction within the Code.
On May 1, 1962, we ordered after arguments were companycluded that the appeal be allowed and the companyviction of the appellant be set aside.
